posts.name: Jordan Grabanski
posts.cooked:
A white paper I recently released has led to a side-discussion about the use of 3D mice in FRC . This poll is aimed at formally gaining insight on the use of these devices by members of the Chief Delphi Community:

I don’t know what a 3D Mouse is. I know what a 3D mouse is, but no member of our team uses one. I know what a 3D mouse is, I personally use one, but no one else on our team does Multiple members of our team use 3D mice, but it is not taught to students. Multiple members of our team use 3D mice, and students are taught to use them. 0 voters

Multiple members of our team use 3D mice, and students are taught to use them.

Please quantify your response in the thread.

838db6c43e4e425b5835623d3875534f.name: I ask a whole lot of questions

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: Many years ago, I purchased a 3D mouse. I didn’t like it very much so now it sits in a drawer.

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: I wasn’t really sure how to answer this, multiple mentors use them on our team, we have some to offer to students, and we DO teach them how to use them, but they tend to not like them so they sit on a shelf. I think this is because they can’t take them home, so its more consistent for them to always use keyboard and mouse.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
We’re similar to Rich.

I bought a wireless SpaceMouse, love it, and use it for anything beyond the most extremely casual CAD exploration. I got one for my kid on the team as well.

The school has the wired version from 3DConnexion and some students use them sometime, but since they only have them in the classroom, they don’t seem as annoyed by 2D mouse usage.  (I get infuriated if I have to a lot of CAD with a 2D mouse.)

posts.name: bradley levesque
posts.cooked: We had 6 space mice and cad mice donated, so we have them at the 6 CAD stations used by the team members

posts.name: Jeremiah Johnson
posts.cooked:
As you can see by the dust, mine doesn’t get much use. I tend to keep views orthogonal. My left hand is most often pressing the Alt key for panning, the spacebar for changing views, or the S-key for the shortcut bar in SW. I try not to judge my students, but most of them are content using the trakpad on their laptops for CAD…

posts.name: Sam Richards
posts.cooked: I started using one my team had lying around after reading that thread yesterday, and it’s been so nice that I’m real tempted to get my own despite what it’d do to my wallet @~@

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: some mentors from a local GE plant brought one over for us to use and i thought it was very cool, but it didn’t work too well with onshape.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I never liked having to go between the space mouse, keyboard, and mouse. I’ve always been more efficient with one hand on the keyboard (hot keys) and one on a regular mouse. My dad bought me one of the original corded 3dconnexion space mice when I was a youngling. It’s been in a drawer for a long time. I work with larger scale models than people in product design - think really heavy industry. I don’t remember seeing a designer or engineer use one in my career.

posts.name: david
posts.cooked: have you tried cadding with a drawing tablet though

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Have you done onshape with the touchscreen of a Nintendo switch? Or is that just me
All roads lead to Rome, just as all screen-related discussions lead to the internet-connected fridge.

My former team had a bunch that I think people did use, but again, they were classroom specific so most just ended up using a regular mouse. @Chris_Ely did use his a lot, but he’s the only one I know.

I know what it is, but don’t use it, but know others who do is the category I would fit in

The budget option in my experience is a trackball, which can get similar motion and movement as a 3d mouse, although I haven’t played with either enough to fully figure that out. (You won’t get the twisting knob on the 3d mouse with a trackball though)

FinIce:

The budget option in my experience is a trackball

I have no idea what to make of this. A 3D mouse has 6 degrees of freedom (translation and rotation on X, Y, and Z); a trackball has only two, maybe three if you count the has a scroll wheel. How is that usable for navigating in CAD (edit: in a way a mouse isn’t)? What CAD programs can use a mouse and trackball simultaneously? I think that’d be the same as having two mice, and I’ve seen software that will show two cursors when there are two mice, but never one that does view control with one and a cursor with the other.

3D mice are fantastic if you use 3D programs from different vendors on any sort of regular basis. Almost every single vendor of 3D software has a different way of using the keyboard and mouse to pan, rotate, and zoom in 3D, and it’s jarring when you switch from one program to another and suddenly the controls are different. A 6 DOF mouse is unambiguous, and apart from speed differences, is interpreted the same in every program.

I have an old wacom bamboo and have done CAD with it. Honestly, not that different from using a mouse. Crucially, the pen has two buttons on its side, which by default map to middle- and right-clicking.

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked: 3D mice really shine when flying through very large models. People get used to them working in industry loading up large sections of vehicles, aircraft, etc. but I get why many won’t find them useful at FRC & FTC scale.

posts.name: Christopher Ely
posts.cooked: I love my Space Mouse. It’s great when switching between different CAD programs that have different movement controls frequently. I use Teamcenter Vis Mockup at work, Onshape for robotics CAD, and Inventor for robotics CAM. I found it took me about a week of using it before it became natural.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked: been looking into a cadmouse pro (I think that’s what it is) just because I like the portability of it and was wondering if anyone has any thoughts on them, right now I have a g305 from Logitech but looking for something better.
